U.S. Market Recovery

 

The above article talks about the current auto industry situation in the United States. The automobile sales in the U.S. have seen a steep rise since 2012 due to the aging vehicles plying on the road and most importantly, the decreasing unemployment rate. While the average age of vehicles in 2012 was 10.8 years, by 2013 it rose to 11.3 years which was a commendable development for the industry.

Automobile sales in the U.S. grew 13.4% to the five year high of 14.5 million vehicles in 2012. By May 2013, auto sales in the U.S. grew by 8.2% to 1.44 million units. As per seasonally adjusted rate (SAAR), the automobile rate rose to 10.9% to 15.3 million units which indeed surprised the industry analysts. They opine that the easy lending and lower interest rates of banks to the automobile consumers played a significant role in the market recovery.

 

Economic Crisis in Europe

Global automakers in the European continent are worst hit due to the present Eurozone financial crisis. It has adversely affected the operations of the automobile makers who have a significant exposure to the market. The crisis has weakened the economy in turn making the consumer save for a rainy day than spend on automobiles.

This has drastically lowered the car sales in Europe to its lowest level of 12.05 million units in 2012 since 1995, indicating a year-over-year decline of 8.2%. The primary reason behind the decline has been sagging demand for cars and highly indebted banks were not keen to finance new car purchases for customers. Reuters opined that the decline was the steepest in the highly troubled Eurozone, dipping to 11.3% to roughly 9 million units.

Major automakers have decided to cut jobs and close the plants, as it has become tough for them to undertake full-fledged operations in the continent. As of March 2013, the unemployment headcount has reached 26.5 million, while the rate increased to 10.9% in the same month from 10.3% in March 2012.

Ford was the first automaker planning to shut its vehicle and component plants in the U.K. and Belgium by 2016 while General Motors will suspend car production at its Bochum plant in Germany, which employs about 3,100 workers by 2016.

Renault is another big name in the automobile industry and plans to bring the jobs in France by 7,500 by 2016. Fiat and Peugeot and close to follow on the hells with a job cut of 1,500 respectively.

Japanese automakers, Honda has been closely monitoring the economic situation in Europe and plans to terminate 800 jobs at its South Marston plant near Swindon, Southwest England by the second quarter of 2013.

June 2013 - Auto Industry Outlook for the US and Europe

U.S. Market Recovery

Strong pent-up demand due to aging vehicles on the U.S. roads along with falling unemployment rate have been the key factors in driving the auto sales in the U.S. Average age of vehicles on U.S. roads increased to 11.3 years in January 2013 from 10.8 years in 2012. Banks were also friendlier as they offered greater access to loans with lower interest rates.

Auto sales in the U.S. grew 13.4% to the five-year high of 14.5 million vehicles in 2012. In May 2013, auto sales in the U.S. grew 8.2% to 1.44 million units while it rose 10.9% to 15.3 million vehicles on a seasonally adjusted rate (SAAR) basis.

Economic Crisis in Europe

The present Eurozone financial crisis has adversely affected the operations of many global automakers, especially GM and Ford, who have a significant exposure to the market. Car sales in Europe continued to be low owing to weak consumer confidence on the back of a weak economy triggered by the crisis.

According to the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA), car sales in Europe reached its lowest level of 12.05 million units in 2012 since 1995, indicating a year-over-year decline of 8.2% due to the sagging demand for cars, as highly indebted banks were reluctant to finance new car purchases for customers. The decline was the steepest in the highly troubled Eurozone, where car sales dipped 11.3% to roughly 9 million units, according to Reuters.

Most of the major automakers in Europe are resorting to job cuts and plant closures, as it became no longer feasible for them to undertake full-fledged operations in the continent. Unemployment in the EU reached 26.5 million in Mar 2013, while the unemployment rate increased to 10.9% in the same month from 10.3% in Mar 2012.

Among the U.S. automakers, Ford plans to shut vehicle and component plants in the U.K. and Belgium in the next two years while General Motors would suspend car production at its Bochum plant in Germany -- which employs 3,100 workers -- in 2016.

Among the European automakers, Renault plans to retrench 7,500 jobs in France by 2016 while each of Fiat and Peugeot has decided to eliminate 1,500 jobs. Among the Japanese automakers, Honda announced plans to terminate 800 jobs at its South Marston plant near Swindon, southwest England in the second quarter of 2013.
